column1: Daloa is a city in western Ivory Coast. It is the seat of both the Sassandra-Marahoué District and the Haut-Sassandra Region. It is also the seat of and a sub-prefecture of Daloa Department. Daloa is also a commune. In the 2014 census
column2: the city had a population of 319
column4: making it the third-largest city in the country. It lies to the west of Yamoussoukro
column5: the capital of Ivory Coast. Daloa is an important trading centre
column6: particularly for cocoa. The city is served by Daloa Airport and is home to the Roman Catholic Diocese of Daloa
column7: with its cathedral at Cathédrale du Christ-Roi.

column2: which lasted from 2002 to 2004. Following the takeover of the town by the government on 16 October 2002
column3: fifty civilians from the north were allegedly killed by government troops. Amnesty International described the killings as a "massacre"
column4: saying people in military uniform had killed people suspected of supporting the rebel Patriotic Movement of Côte d'Ivoire. The killings were allegedly based on their Muslim names or that the victims were nationals of Mali
column5: Burkino Faso or Guinea. Côte d'Ivoire authorities ordered an inquiry but stated government forces had not been responsible. However
column6: no charges were brought and the Ouagadougou Peace Agreement in March 2007 between President Laurent Gbagbo and rebel leader Guillaume Soro incorporated a general amnesty for crimes committed in this time
